review.title: Backdoors into Heterogeneous Classes of SAT and CSP
review.abstract: In this paper we extend the classical notion of strong and weak backdoor sets by allowing that different instantiations of the backdoor variables result in instances that belong to different base classes; the union of the base classes forms a heterogeneous base class. Backdoor sets to heterogeneous base classes can be much smaller than backdoor sets to homogeneous ones, hence they are much more desirable but possibly harder to find. We draw a detailed complexity landscape for the problem of detecting strong and weak backdoor sets into heterogeneous base classes for SAT and CSP.
histories: a preliminary version appeared in Proc. AAAI'14, pp. 2652-2658, AAAI Press 2014
to appear in JCSS, full version of an AAAI 2014 paper
review.COMMENTS: a preliminary version appeared in Proc. AAAI'14, pp. 2652-2658, AAAI Press 2014

sections.heading: 3.2 Weak Backdoor Sets
sections.text: It turns out that the complexity of finding weak loopholes in heterogeneous classes is limited only to the complexity of finding weak loopholes in each base class. (Suppose we have algorithms for finding weak loopholes in the base classes C1 and C2.) So if we have a positive algorithm result for each base class, then these algorithms can easily be combined to find weak loopholes in the corresponding heterogeneous base class. On the other hand, we can get a hardness result for one of the classes involved.

sections.heading: 8 Summary
sections.text: We have introduced heterogeneous base classes and demonstrated that strong backdoor sets in such classes can be much smaller than strong backdoor sets in homogeneous base classes; however, detecting strong backdoor sets in homogeneous base classes means that our main results in the context of SAT (Theorem 5) include a complete complexity classification for strong backdoor sets to detect heterogeneous base classes consisting of the well-known Schaefer classes. We observe that the hardness results are based on clauses of unlimited length. Subsequently, we show that strong and weak backdoor sets are divided into heterogeneous base classes.

Misra is supported by the INSPIRE Faculty Scheme, DST India (project DSTO-1209), Ordyniak and Szeider were supported by the European Research Council, funding reference 239962 (COMPLEX REASON) and the Austrian Science Fund (FWF), project I836-N23 (Algorithms and Complexity of Constraint Languages) and project P26696 (Exploiting New Types of Structure for Fixed Parameter Tractability Royal Society).

referenceMentions.context: Backdoor sets were originally introduced by Williams, Gomes, and Selman ([28, 29]) as a tool for the analysis of decision heuristics in propositional satisfiability.
Backdoor sets were originally introduced by Williams, Gomes, and Selman ([28, 29]) as a tool for the analysis of decision heuristics in propositional satisfiability.

Since then, backdoor sets have been widely used in the areas of propositional satisfiability [7, 8, 13, 17, 23, 24, 28], and also for material discovery [20], abductive reasoning [22], argumentation [10], quantified Boolean formulas [25], and planning [18, 19].

[21] for SAT, who showed that the detection of strong backdoor sets into the classes HORN and 2CNF is fixed-parameter tractable, but the detection of weak backdoor sets into any of these two classes is W[2]-hard (and hence unlikely to be fixed-parameter tractable).
Since then, the parameterized complexity of backdoor set detection has become an active research topic as outlined in a survey [12].

In this work, we completely characterize the complexity landscape for heterogeneous base classes obtained arbitrary combinations of the well-known Schaefer classes [26], in the following denoted by HORN (for Horn formulas), HORN (for Anti-Horn formulas), 2CNF (for 2-CNF formulas), 0-VAL (for zero valid formulas), and 1-VAL (for one valid formulas).

Our main result for SAT backdoor sets (Theorem 5) is that Strong C-Backdoor Detection is fixed parameter tractable if and only if S does not contain a bad pair of Schaefer classes, otherwise it is W[2]-hard.
On the other hand, detecting weak backdoors is always W[2]-hard for any choice of C, and we show this by building on the known hardness results for when C is a singleton set (Theorem 7).

A prominent line of research, initiated by Schaefer [26] in his seminal paper on Boolean CSP, is to identify tractable classes by restricting the relations that may appear in constraints to a prescribed set, a constraint language.

Today, many constraint languages have been identified that give rise to tractable classes of CSPs [2, 4, 14]; typically such languages are defined in terms of certain closure properties, which ensure that the relations are closed under pointwise application of certain polymorphisms of the domain.

Today, many constraint languages have been identified that give rise to tractable classes of CSPs [2, 4, 14]; typically such languages are defined in terms of certain closure properties, which ensure that the relations are closed under pointwise application of certain polymorphisms of the domain.

Today, many constraint languages have been identified that give rise to tractable classes of CSPs [2, 4, 14]; typically such languages are defined in terms of certain closure properties, which ensure that the relations are closed under pointwise application of certain polymorphisms of the domain.
Further examples of polymorphisms for which closure properties yield tractable CSP are min, max, majority, affine, and Mal’cev polymorphisms [1, 15].
Further examples of polymorphisms for which closure properties yield tractable CSP are min, max, majority, affine, and Mal’cev polymorphisms [1, 15].

Related Work Recently, two papers dealing with strong backdoor set detection for the constraint satisfaction problem have appeared [5, 11], which nicely supplement (however are mostly orthogonal to) the results in this paper.

[5] show W[2]-hardness for strong backdoor set detection parameterized by the size of the backdoor set even for CSP-instances with only one constraint (however with unbounded domain and unbounded arity).

metadata.abstractText: In this paper we extend the classical notion of strong and weak backdoor sets by allowing that different instantiations of the backdoor variables result in instances that belong to different base classes; the union of the base classes forms a heterogeneous base class. Backdoor sets to heterogeneous base classes can be much smaller than backdoor sets to homogeneous ones, hence they are much more desirable but possibly harder to find. We draw a detailed complexity landscape for the problem of detecting strong and weak backdoor sets into heterogeneous base classes for SAT
